docs.lead_paragraph: There just hasn't been a lot of good news about long-term care insurance lately. Private insurers have been dropping the product, and the Obama administration announced last fall that it was scrapping plans for a federally sponsored option. The latest? The American Association for Long-Term Care Insurance says its yearly analysis of popular policies offered by 10 big insurers finds that prices for such policies have risen by as much as 17 percent from a year ago.
docs.abstract: Bucks blog notes that prices for long-term care policies offered by 10 major insurance providers have risen by as much as 17 percent from period a year earlier. Photo (M)1

headline.main: Romney Is Endorsed by Chicago Tribune

docs.abstract: The Tribune's editorial board called Mitt Romney "the Republicans' best, most responsible choice in Tuesday's Illinois primary," but Rick Santorum expressed confidence while campaigning in the state.

headline.main: The Early Word: Courting the Hispanic Vote

docs.abstract: Republicans try to lure Hispanic voters away from the Democrats, while the Obama campaign sends Vice President Biden out on the stump and on the attack.

docs.lead_paragraph: Worried about further alienating women in this year’s elections, Republican leaders are carefully reviewing their options on efforts to overturn a federal health insurance rule.

headline.seo: House Republicans Hesitate on Birth Control Mandate
headline.main: House G.O.P. Hesitates on Birth Control Fight
headline.print_headline: House G.O.P. Hesitates On Birth Control Fight

docs.abstract: House Republicans have slowed their efforts to overturn a federal rule requiring employers, including religious institutions, to provide female employees with free health insurance coverage for contraceptives, fearful of giving political ammunition to Democrats and further alienating women voters.
docs.snippet: Worried about further alienating women in this year’s elections, Republican leaders are carefully reviewing their options on efforts to overturn a federal health insurance rule.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sidney Crosby was limited to a supporting role, getting one assist, but the rest of the Penguins kept rolling in a victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

headline.seo: Crosby Climbs Aboard a Rolling Team as Penguins Beat Rangers
headline.main: Crosby Climbs Aboard a Steamrolling Team
headline.print_headline: Crosby Climbs Aboard A Steamrolling Team

docs.abstract: Pittsburgh Penguins defeat New York Rangers, 5-2, in NHL action; Penguins center Sidney Crosby, appearing in his first game since Dec 2011, plays a supporting role in the win.
docs.snippet: Sidney Crosby was limited to a supporting role, getting one assist, but the rest of the Penguins kept rolling in a victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

docs.lead_paragraph: The extended ad isn’t telling voters that everything is rosy after three years of the Obama presidency. Instead, it suggests that it could all have been so much worse.

headline.seo: Obama Campaign Video Plays It Stark
headline.main: Obama Campaign Video Serves Up a Heroic Vision of Catastrophe Averted
headline.print_headline: Obama Campaign Video Serves Up a Heroic Vision of Catastrophe Averted

docs.abstract: Alessandra Stanley analyzes The Road We've Traveled, Pres Obama's 17-minute re-election documentary, noting that it paints a heroic picture of a leader who led the US away from the brink of catastrophe during his first term.
docs.snippet: The extended ad isn’t telling voters that everything is rosy after three years of the Obama presidency. Instead, it suggests that it could all have been so much worse.

docs.lead_paragraph: Four conservative Republican senators kicked off a conversation Thursday on changes to Medicare, releasing a proposal that would end the federal fee-for-service insurance program in 2014 and enroll all recipients into the health insurance plan now offered to federal employees. The proposal establishes a right flank for the coming debate over the benefits program, which is expected to begin in earnest on Tuesday when the House Budget Committee, led by Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, unveils the Republicans' plan. This proposal is expected to embrace ideas that Mr. Ryan wrote with Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, which would give seniors and other recipients a menu of health insurance plans to choose from, including the existing fee-for-service program. Seniors would be given a fixed subsidy to buy an insurance plan.
docs.abstract: Republican Sens Rand Paul, Jim DeMint, Lindsey Graham and Mike Lee issue a tentative proposal that would end the fee-for-service Medicare system in 2014 and enroll all recipients in the health insurance plan now offered to federal employees; proposal establishes a right flank for the debate over the program when the House Budget Committee unveils its newest Republican budget proposal. (M)
